Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

contract.

ALLEGATION:
On 2/14/22022, Foster Parent A was involved in a serious incident and is being
arrested for felony homicide. Law Enforcement (LE) indicated that there was a
history of domestic violence between Foster Parent A and the other individual; and a
personal protection order (PPO) was in place. The foster parent’s renewal report
indicates the foster parent reports no domestic violence history or current
relationship. There is information in the renewal report that there are firearms in the
home. There is concern the agency did not adequately assess the foster home.
INVESTIGATION:
On 2/18/2022 I reviewed the complaint document which indicated the information
above about the serious felony incident, domestic violence, and PPO allegations and
what Foster Parent A’s renewal report indicates. The complaint document further
indicated:
 An arrest notification was received by the Division of Child Welfare Licensing
(DCWL) for Foster Parent A indicating Foster Parent A was arrested for
felony homicide.
 Per Ennis, Foster Parent A denied being in a relationship.
 Foster Parent A is a state employee for another county. Foster Parent A
admitted to using substances while caring for Foster Child B who was placed
in her home.
 Foster Child B is an Ingham County youth. Foster Child B was in route to
school, and not in the home at the time of the shooting.
 Foster Child B’s placement is by way of a borrowed bed with Ennis-Pontiac.
On 3/2/2022, I completed an onsite agency visit. I met with Licensee Designee 0,
Licensing Supervisor 2 and reviewed licensing documentations:
Licensee Designee 0 and Licensing Supervisor 1 confirmed that Ennis Center for
Children-Pontiac was the certifying agency for Foster Parent A; and that the Ingham
County Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) was borrowing a bed in
Foster Parent A’s home for Foster Child B. Foster Child B was placed with Foster
Parent A in July 2021 and Ingham County DHHS has responsibility for monthly foster
care worker visits to the foster home, and Foster Child B’s case services. Licensee
Designee 0 reported, Ingham County DHHS had not reported any concerns to Ennis
related to Foster Parent A or Child B’s placement.
Licensing Supervisor 1 reported Ennis would have only had periodic or quarterly
contacts with Foster Parent A. These contacts would have consisted of checking to
see if there was something Foster Parent A may have needed related to the license.
Licensing Supervisor 1 reported Ennis’s last contact would have been to complete
Foster Parent A’s relocation study in January 2022. She, as well as Licensee
Designee 0 both verified that Ennis has a special evaluation underway related to the
3

shooting incident and allegations indicated in the complaint against Foster Parent A.
Both administrators denied the agency having prior knowledge of any information
related to domestic violence for Foster Parent A or information related to her being in
a relationship with anyone. Both administrators also acknowledged the special
circumstances related to this complaint, given Foster Parent A's relationship with the
Department, and the circumstance of this complaint. Licensing Supervisor 1 reported
this complaint is the first special evaluation for Foster Parent A.
Licensing Supervisor 1 advised that Foster Parent A’s reevaluation was current at the
time of this incident. The agency completed the Renewal Reevaluation; and most
recently a Relocation Study in January 2022. Licensing Supervisor 1 reported Foster
Parent A would have signed three series of policies, inclusive of a weapon’s policy.
Licensing Supervisor 1 reported Foster Parent A had reported multiple times, she has
no significant other, was not in a relationship, and that there was no drug use or
substance issues for her. Licensing Supervisor 1 reported since the complaint
allegations, the agency discovered (by way of the LE investigation) Foster Parent A
admitted to using cocaine the night before the shooting. Licensing Supervisor 1
admitted at the time of Ennis’s licensing worker’s January 2022 Relocation Study, the
licensing worker did not complete a Children’s Foster Home Rules Compliance
Record (CWL-3080) or document where Foster Parent A would keep the guns, that
Foster Parent A reported having during the foster home’s Renewal Inspection.
Licensing Supervisor 1 surmised the licensing worker would have had verbal
discussions with the family about the weapons. She advised given the past policy
signing by Foster Parent A that Foster Parent A should have been abreast of the
agency and licensing requirements related to having a weapon in the home.
Licensing Supervisor 1 and Licensee Designee 0 reported grounds for revocation of
Foster Parent A’s license seems feasible and is being assessed via the special
evaluation investigation.
Licensee Designee 0 reported further via email on 3/11/2022 that Foster Parent A
never disclosed having a concealed weapons permit. The guns were initially disclosed
at the renewal evaluation inspection. The guns were not there at the initial evaluation
inspection. He provided Foster Parent A signed a weapon’s policy dated 8/2/2021.
On 3/2/2022, while onsite, I interviewed Licensing Worker 2. Licensing Worker 2
reported being employed by Ennis, since 12/2/2019. She completed Foster Parent
A’s 12/22/2020 Initial Foster Home Evaluation (DCWL-3130); and the foster home’s
1/7/2021 Relocation Study. Another worker, who is no longer with the agency,
completed the foster home’s Renewal Inspection.
Licensing Worker 2 reported Foster Parent A informed the agency in December 2021
that Foster Parent A was buying a new home; and the foster parent kept the agency
abreast so that the agency could come out and inspect the new home. Licensing
Worker 2 reported completing the usual tasks during the Relocation Inspection. She
reported those tasks consisted of signing a new application; touring the home,
checking water temperature, cleaning supply storage, inquiring/checking to see if
4

there were pets, and inquiring about a significant relationship. Licensing Worker 2
reported during the Relocation Inspection, Foster Parent A denied having a significant
relationship, as was reported in the Initial Licensing Study. Foster Parent A also again
denied involvement with drugs or alcohol. Licensing Worker 2 reported she has never
observed Foster Parent A to appear under the influence of any substances, other than
that Foster Parent A was a cigarette smoker.
Licensing Worker 2 affirmed Licensing Supervisor 1’s reporting that she did not
complete the CWL-3080 during the Relocation Inspection. She did not know she was
required to do so. She reported Licensing Supervisor 1 knew she was completing the
Relocation Inspection, but this supervisor was new to licensing also, and the
information they reviewed to assist them on how to go about completing the
Relocation Inspection did not indicate a need to complete the 3080 document.
Licensing Worker 2 acknowledged that some items were missed in the Relocation
Inspection because she did not use the CWL-3080. She reported modeling her report
after a 2020 example.
Licensing Worker 2 reported asking Foster Parent A about the three guns, which
Foster Parent A reported being in the home during the Renewal Inspection Report.
Foster Parent A reported the guns were still stored at the home she moved from.
Foster Parent A had not fully moved all her items into the home and anticipated doing
so later the day of Licensing worker 2’s home visit, or the next day. Licensing Worker
2 did not check to see if the guns, sword, and rifle were in the home. Foster Parent A
reported she was taking those items to her grandmother’s home until she was able to
put a lock on her bedroom door. Foster Parent A also reported needing to obtain a
lock box for medication storage.
Licensing Worker 2 did not go back out to the home to check/assess whether the
stated weapons were back in the home; and if so, whether they were properly stored,
per rule. She did not report whether she inquired about a gun or CCW (Carrying
Concealed Weapon) license for Foster Parent A. Licensing Worker 2 reported as far
as she knew the guns were at Foster Parent A’s grandmother’s home. She thought
this, because at the time of the home visit to Foster Parent A’s home related to the
agency’s special evaluation for this shotting incident, Foster Parent A still did not have
a lock on her bedroom door. Licensing Worker 2 reported she discovered (via the
police report pertaining to the shooting Foster Parent A was involved in), her belief
was in error, because apparently at least one gun was in the home, which was used
by the Foster Parent A in the shooting incident. Licensing Worker 2 expressed
distress over not checking all items during the Relocation Inspection, but logically
knows even if she had, and the documentation was in the Relocation Study, such
could not have prevented the shooting Foster Parent A is accused of.
5

Reviewed:
Foster Parent A’s Licensing documents and MISACWIS file which showed:
 Foster Parent A was licensed by Ennis Center for Children on 3/19/2021.
 Foster Parent A’s Initial Foster/Adoption Home Evaluation (CWL-3130) was
dated 12/22/2020, and documented that Foster Parent A:
 Had provided relative care/placement to her 15-year-old sister prior to
licensure (5/10/2019-8/5/2020).
 Resided in her home with her 37-year-old, younger brother at the time of
the original licensing evaluation.
 Reported no weapons were stored in the home and medication was
secured in a locked box.
 Reported no childhood abuse or victimization. Nor a history of domestic
violence.
 Reported not being married or in a relationship at the time of the
evaluation.
 Reported with the exception of taking a blood thinner, Xarelto(20mg) and
Wellbutrin (typically used for depression) prescribed to help her quit
smoking, was not using any forms of drugs. She denied a history of
alcohol abuse.
 Was found in compliance with all licensing rules and was approved for two
children, cross racial, age 12 to 18.
 Foster Parent A’s Foster Home Reevaluation (CWL-4004) for 3/19/2021-
9/18/2021, completed 8/20/2021, which indicated:
 A foster home visit by the worker on 8/2/2021 and 8/18/2021.
 Foster Parent A’s brother moved out the foster home during the licensing
period.
 Foster Parent A reported no history of separations or domestic violence;
and that she is not currently in a relationship.
 Two handguns, one rifle, and a small sword were reported in the home.
The handguns were stored in a locked metal case; the rifle was trigger
locked; and the sword was kept on a high shelf in Foster Parent A’s
bedroom closet. The ammunition was kept separately; the key was kept
on Foster Parent A’s person. The worker assessed the weapons and
ammunition were properly stored and not accessible to children in the
home.
 Two children were placed in the home during the reevaluation.
 No reported changes in Foster Parent A’s physical, mental, emotional
health or substance use during this licensure period.
 Foster Parent A’s medications were reported as Alprazolam(0.05mg) for
anxiety; Modafinil(200mg) for narcolepsy; Fusion Plus for probiotics, and a
CPAP machine, used every night for sleep apnea. The only side effect
reported was back pain due the Modafinil.
 Full licensing and agency policy compliance was assessed, and a regular
license was recommended by the agency and issued by the Department.
6

 This reevaluation did not indicate whether Foster Parent A’s handguns
were registered, or whether she also had a CCW license.
 Relocation Study dated 1/7/2022 which indicated:
 The foster home’s identifying information and the home’s new address.
 The home visit date as 12/22/2021. It is noteworthy that this date is not
listed as a social work contact in MISACWIS.
 Household members, which listed the name of one foster child, Foster
Child B (It is noteworthy Foster Child B was replaced from the home on
2/14/2022).
 A section on directions to the home, the neighborhood; home description
as observed via a walk through. Compliance to water temperature,
carbon monoxide detector and smoke detectors were noted, as well as,
appropriate sleeping arrangements and bedroom sizes and window
egress.
 Aside from the above the only other section listed on the Relocation Study
is the Recommendation section, recommending a continued regular
license for two children ages 12-18.
 The Relocation is signed by Licensing Worker 2 and Licensing Supervisor
1 for 1/7/2022.
 This Relocation Study did not indicate whether Foster Parent A’s
handguns were registered, or whether she also had a CCW license.
 An Officer Narrative document listed as entered on 2/15/2022; and as printed on
2/17/2022. This document contained a summary of the police’s interview with
Foster Parent A and her attorney related to events prior and leading to the
shooting incident. The Narrative document indicated information Foster Parent A
reported which was contradictory to what she had reported to the Ennis during
her initial, renewal and relocation foster home evaluations about being in a
relationship, current or past history of domestic violence, any alcohol abuse or
drug use or abuse; or having guns at the new location. Foster Parent A reported:
 A past and current relationship with Person X prior to the shooting. This
relationship began when she was age 15; and had ended because of
“domestic violence”. She reconnected with Person X three years ago.
 Person X’s and her living arrangement in December was that he stayed at
her house for a week or two but lived elsewhere.
 She obtained a PPO (Person Protection Order) against Person X in June
or July of last year. Person X had grabbed, choked and threatened to kill
her and her family, as well as sent her threatening text messages.
Additionally, Person X had been “too aggressive” to her a time in
December; and she contacted the police. She reported Person X had
“jumped on her several times”.
 The night before the shooting, she and Person X were drinking and both
snorted cocaine. This was at her house in the basement. Person X was
7

intoxicated, and she had a “little buzz”. She also reported, “they were
high”.
 The morning of the shooting, a domestic violence incident occurred
between she and Person X. This incident led to her obtaining: keys from a
safe from underneath her mattress; a gun and shooting Person X at least
once.
 Having the gun (which she thought was a Ruger or Luger 9MM) for about
a year. It is the gun she carries if she wants to carry. The gun was loaded
when she grabbed it from the safe, it is registered to her. She reported
having other registered guns and did not have any guns that were not
registered to her. She reported having a CPL (Concealed Pistol License).
 Ennis Children for Children’s Weapon’s Agreement signed by Foster Parent A
and an agency staff person on 8/1/2021 and 8/2/2021 respectively. The
Agreement showed:
 The box for having weapons in the home was checked.
 Handgun and rifle was handwritten in the area of that indicated line.
 Ennis requires foster parents/adoptive parents who have ownership of a
weapon to show they have a registered permit for the weapon and a
Michigan concealed Pistol License. Additionally, that the foster
parent/adoptive parent provide a copy of the permit and license to the
licensing worker.
 A copy of such a permit or license was not documented in the evaluation
or MISACWIS for Foster Parent A.
8

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination
and assessment of all of the following:
(a) All changes to the factual information contained in
the initial evaluation and subsequent renewal
evaluations.
ANALYSIS The agency’s reevaluation for Foster Parent A’s Renewal
Inspection and the one conducted for Foster Parent A’s
Relocation Study did not document a thorough assessment of
relevant changes since the last evaluation.
The revaluation for the foster parent’s Renewal Inspection and
Relocation Study did not indicate whether Foster Parent A’s
handguns were registered, or whether she also had a CCW
(Carrying Concealed Weapon) license. Nor showed that a copy
of the guns’ registrations and or licenses were obtained from the
foster parent.
Licensing Worker 2 reported Foster Parent A had not completely
moved into the new home when Licensing Worker 2 made the
home visit for the relocation inspection. Licensing Worker 2 did
not complete another home visit to inspect whether any or all of
the weapons reported as being in the home during the Renewal
Inspection were in the new home and stored securely.
Additionally, the Relocation Study does not document whether
Foster Parent A’s relationship status changed since the last
evaluation. Nor was it documented in the report that was
explored as reported by the worker.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination
and assessment of all of the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as
determined by observation of, and interviews with, each
member of the household and each social service
worker who has had children placed in the home during
the last licensing period.
ANALYSIS: The evidence as illustrated during Foster Parent A’s interview
with the police showed Foster Parent A was not honest with the
agency about having a significant relationship, anyone else
living with her, or any domestic violence or drug use.
The agency would be unable to assess a relationship, a
situation of drug use or domestic violence or have an interview
with a temporary household member that and whom they were
not aware of.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination
and assessment of all of the following:
(d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster homes.
ANALYSIS: The agency admitted and Foster Parent A’s provider record
showed the agency did not complete a Children’s Foster Home
Compliance Records (CWL-3080) showing all rules were
reviewed/ assessed for the inspection. Nor that a copy of Foster
Parent A guns’ permits, or licenses were obtained/documented.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
APPLICABLE RULE
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
Social work contacts are to be entered in MISACWIS the
DHHS- primary tracking system to satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
ANALYSIS: The agency did not document the worker’s 12/22/2021
relocation home visit in MISACWIS as required.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency’s
current licensing status is recommended.

sir_summary.summary: A licensed foster parent was arrested for felony homicide after a shooting incident that involved domestic violence and substance use, which contradicted the information she provided during her foster home reevaluation and relocation study. The agency, Ennis Center for Children, failed to adequately assess changes in the foster home, including verifying weapon registration and storage, checking for relationship changes or domestic violence, and documenting required compliance records, leading to substantiated violations. The agency is culpable for not following proper reevaluation procedures, while the foster parent misled the agency.
